text:
Bellevue Hospital: The old wards (1811-1855) and Chapel (1888) surrounded by the modern units. These border on the east side of First Avenue, at the foot of 27th Street. They were demolished in 1938. A modern administration building is under construction here in 1940. At the left of View 1 is the wing containing the Mortuary. This is at 29th Street. Note the row of tenements above, that were demolished and replaced with the modern Psychiatric Division. On the right of View 2 is the Out Patient Department building at 26th Street, erected 1925.

View 1: September 10, 1928
View 2: June 16, 1934

P. L. Sperr
title: Hospitals - Bellevue Hospital - [Old wards and Chapel.]

text:

title: Hospitals - Bellevue Hospital - [Old wards and Chapel.]

text:
First Ave., west side, north from and including East 27th to and including East 28th Streets. Building concerned is Cornell Clinic, of the New York University.

About 1933.

Ewing Galloway.

Bellevue Hospital: A set of three views showing the old buildings under demolition. These are on the east side of First Ave; the photographer standing on the opposite side at East 27th Street. From right to left, they are the Administration Building (former House of Refuge); the nurses and doctors (residential) wing, which was formerly a prison and the Chapel. Encircling same are modern hospital structures which in the same order are: the Out Patient Building, the new Administration Building and Tubercular Ward, several ward buildings and finally the Medical Examiners and Hospital Office Building; the latter containing the Morgue.

May 8, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Hospitals - Bellevue Hospital - [Old buildings under demolition.]
